fields.title: Consider HotFix support for git-flow
fields.body:
When you are working with git-flow [1], there are times when you need to merge a hotfix into the stable branch and also into the active development branch.  It would be really convenient if there was consideration for this use-case in Gitblit.

One possibility is to implement an automatic, semantic-versioning-based merge mechanism as a plugin.  This would essentially be what Stash offers [2].

Another approach would be to create a *hotfix* ticket which allowed you to merge the patchset of a ticket into multiple target branches.  The *hotfix* ticket branch would be required to have a merge base in the stable branch - i.e. you could not hotfix the *develop* branch.  This may require teaching Gitblit more about the git-flow workflow.

- [1] http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model
- [2] https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Automatic+branch+merging

fields.title: Make Git-flow simple with branches and tickets
fields.body:
**Hotfix Tickets**

When you are working with git-flow [1], there are times when you need to merge a hotfix into the stable branch and also into the active development branch.  It would be really convenient if there was consideration for this use-case in Gitblit.

One possibility is to implement an automatic, semantic-versioning-based merge mechanism as a plugin.  This would essentially be what Stash offers [2].

Another approach would be to create a *hotfix* ticket which allowed you to merge the patchset of a ticket into multiple target branches.  The *hotfix* ticket branch would be required to have a merge base in the stable branch - i.e. you could not hotfix the *develop* branch.  This may require teaching Gitblit more about the git-flow workflow.

**Release branches from Milestones**

Another idea is to manage the release branch from creation, to merging & tagging based on a milestone.

1. create milestone *v1.2.3*
2. commit & merge several tickets to *develop* assigned to milestone *v1.2.3*
3. create *release-v1.2.3* branch off of *develop* from the *v1.2.3* milestone
4. commit & merge any new tickets to *release-v1.2.3*
5. merge *release-v1.2.3* to *master* and tag as *v1.2.3*
6. merge *release-v1.2.3* to *develop*
7. delete *release-v1.2.3*


- [1] http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model
- [2] https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Automatic+branch+merging

comment.text:
I have also difficulties when trying to merge a hotfix into the stable branch and also into the active development branch. 

What I would like to see is multiple patchsets for different branches in a single ticket. At the moment I can only reference a ticket, but not (additionally) a branch. E.g. I can only specify "refs/for/{id}", but not "refs/for/{id}/{branch}"

I also could think of a "cherry-pick-button". It would try to cherry-pick a patchset (= one or multiple commits) into another branch. An example:

- master = development branch
- release-v1 = stable branch v1
1. Developer does a hotfix (patchset) in the development branch
2. The owner of the repo (or whoever is responsible) can now verify it and merge it to the master branch
3. With the new "cherry-pick-button" the owner can now cherry-pick the patchset into the release-v1 branch (or any other branch)
 4. If it is not possible because of conflicts, I would like to be able to submit a rebased patchset for this branch (this is where you probably need "refs/for/{id}/{branch}")
